Dear Bertram, I have Just recently received a letter from our Area Manager in India, who, as you know, is also Managing Director of Indian Trane-Continental Airways. Mr. Sutherland had recently met the Indian Foreign Secretary and they had apparently exchanged views about Jask, in view of the fact that negotiations are at present going on between the Governments of India and Persia in connection with a general trade Treaty. Apparently Mr. Metcalfe, the Foreign Secretary, told Mr. Sutherland that unfortunately India had less to offer the Persians than she wanted from them, and as in negotiating with Persia it is necessary to set one con cession against another, he did not see any way in which he could throw into the belting pot* our particular difficulty at Jask, without complicating other issues which were already difficult enough. As you know, the Gwadar/Sharjah bottle neck is of great importance to us, and I, therefore, bring this matter of the negotiations between India and Persia to your notice in case the appropriate Departments at home should consider that the use of Jask could be raised in these negotiations without the home Government in any way losing face with the Persians. If you consider the circumstances Justify your approaching one of your colleagues in the India Office in this matter, I should be very glad to hear in due course their views on the suggestion. F.G.L.Bertram Es q », C.B.E., Yours sincerely, Air Ministry, (Sgd.) H. Burohall Gwydyr House, S.? .1.

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence for this description commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 27; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence related to a forced landing by aircraft Helenaof Imperial Airways at Jask on 16 May 1934. The flight in question was carrying the Viceroy of India, Freeman Freeman-Thomas, and his wife Marie Adelaide (Lord and Lady Willingdon): see folio 4 for a detailed account of the flight. It also contains prior correspondence – from April 1934 – regarding a request from Imperial Airways for emergency landing rights at Jask.The main correspondents are as follows: Francis George Lawder Bertram representing the Air Ministry, George William Rendel representing the Foreign Office, and John Gilbert Laithwaite representing the India Office.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
